hints.label: def-state-spatial-config
hints.title: State and Spatial Configuration Spaces
hints.content:
267: :label: def-state-spatial-config
268: 
269: The **state configuration space** is the orbifold of full walker states:
270: 
271: $$
272: \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{state}} = \Sigma_N / S_N = \left[(\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N\right] / S_N
273: 
274: $$
275: 
276: where $\mathcal{X}$ is position space, $\mathcal{V}$ is velocity space, and $\{0,1\}$ is alive/dead status.
277: 
278: The **spatial configuration space** is the orbifold of positions only:
279: 
280: $$
281: \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{spatial}} = \mathcal{X}^N / S_N
282: 
283: $$
284: 
285: The **projection map** forgets velocities and status:
286: 
287: $$
288: p: \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{state}} \to \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{spatial}}, \quad [(x_1, v_1, s_1), \ldots, (x_N, v_N, s_N)] \mapsto [x_1, \ldots, x_N]

hints.label: def-nonsingular-loci
hints.title: Non-Singular Loci
hints.content:
294: :label: def-nonsingular-loci
295: 
296: The **non-singular state configuration space** consists of states where no two walkers are identical:
297: 
298: $$
299: \mathcal{M}'^{\text{state}}_{\text{config}} = \{[\mathcal{S}] \in \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{state}} : w_i \neq w_j \text{ for all } i \neq j\}
300: 
301: $$
302: 
303: The **non-singular spatial configuration space** consists of positions where no two walkers coincide:
304: 
305: $$
306: \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}} = \{[x_1, \ldots, x_N] \in \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{\text{spatial}} : x_i \neq x_j \text{ for all } i \neq j\}
307: 
308: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-67
hints.content:
325: 
326: :::{prf:proof}
327: **Classical result**: This is a foundational theorem in algebraic topology (Artin, Fox-Neuwirth). The configuration space of $N$ unordered distinct points in $\mathbb{R}^d$ has fundamental group isomorphic to the braid group $B_N$.
328: 
329: **Detailed construction**: A loop $\gamma: [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ with $\gamma(0) = \gamma(1) = [x_1^0, \ldots, x_N^0]$ corresponds to $N$ continuous paths $x_i(t)$ in $\mathcal{X}$ that avoid collisions ($x_i(t) \neq x_j(t)$ for $i \neq j$) and return to the same unordered set at $t=1$.

hints.title: Fundamental Group Isomorphism
hints.content:
335: :label: thm-fundamental-group-isomorphism
336: 
337: The projection $p: \mathcal{M}'^{\text{state}}_{\text{config}} \to \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ induces an isomorphism on fundamental groups:

340: p_*: \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{state}}_{\text{config}}) \xrightarrow{\cong} \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}) \cong B_N(\mathcal{X})
341: 
342: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-88
hints.content:
346: 
347: :::{prf:proof}
348: We use the **long exact sequence of homotopy groups** for a fiber bundle.
349: 
350: **Step 1: Identify the fiber**. For a point $[x_1, \ldots, x_N] \in \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ with all positions distinct, the fiber is:
351: 
352: $$
353: F = p^{-1}([x_1, \ldots, x_N]) = (\mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N / S_N^{\text{fix}}
354: 
355: $$
356: 
357: where $S_N^{\text{fix}}$ is the subgroup of permutations that fix the position ordering (trivial for generic positions).
358: 
359: For generic points (all $x_i$ distinct), the fiber is simply:
360: 
361: $$
362: F \cong (\mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N
363: 
364: $$
365: 
366: since the permutation action is free.
367: 
368: **Step 2: Show fiber is contractible**. The velocity space $\mathcal{V} = \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ is a closed ball, which is contractible. The discrete space $\{0,1\}$ is also contractible (to either point). Therefore:
369: 
370: $$
371: F = (\mathcal{V})^N \times (\{0,1\})^N \text{ is contractible}
372: 
373: $$
374: 
375: **Step 3: Apply the long exact sequence**. For a fiber bundle $F \to E \xrightarrow{p} B$ with contractible fiber, the long exact sequence of homotopy groups gives:
376: 
377: $$
378: \cdots \to \pi_1(F) \to \pi_1(E) \xrightarrow{p_*} \pi_1(B) \to \pi_0(F) \to \cdots
379: 
380: $$
381: 
382: Since $F$ is contractible, $\pi_1(F) = 0$ and $\pi_0(F) = \{*\}$ (single component). The sequence simplifies to:
383: 
384: $$
385: 0 \to \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{state}}_{\text{config}}) \xrightarrow{p_*} \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}) \to 0
386: 
387: $$
388: 
389: This is exact, so $p_*$ is an **isomorphism**:
390: 
391: $$
392: \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{state}}_{\text{config}}) \cong \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}) \cong B_N(\mathcal{X})
393: 
394: $$

hints.label: def-braid-group
hints.title: Braid Group
hints.content:
402: :label: def-braid-group
403: 
404: The **$N$-strand braid group** $B_N$ is the group of isotopy classes of braids on $N$ strands.
405: 
406: **Algebraic presentation**: $B_N$ is generated by $N-1$ generators $\{\sigma_1, \ldots, \sigma_{N-1}\}$ (elementary braids crossing strand $i$ over strand $i+1$) subject to:
407: 
408: 1. **Far commutativity**: $\sigma_i \sigma_j = \sigma_j \sigma_i$ for $|i - j| \geq 2$
409: 2. **Braid relation**: $\sigma_i \sigma_{i+1} \sigma_i = \sigma_{i+1} \sigma_i \sigma_{i+1}$ for all $i$
hints.section: ## 3. The Braid Group and Gauge Connection

399: ### 3.2. The Braid Group and Permutation Homomorphism

401: :::{prf:definition} Braid Group
402: :label: def-braid-group
403: 
404: The **$N$-strand braid group** $B_N$ is the group of isotopy classes of braids on $N$ strands.
405:

407:

409: 2. **Braid relation**: $\sigma_i \sigma_{i+1} \sigma_i = \sigma_{i+1} \sigma_i \sigma_{i+1}$ for all $i$

hints.label: thm-braid-to-permutation
hints.title: Canonical Homomorphism to Permutations
hints.content:
415: :label: thm-braid-to-permutation
416: 
417: There exists a canonical surjective group homomorphism:
418: 
419: $$
420: \rho: B_N \to S_N
421: 
422: $$
423: 
424: that maps each braid to the **net permutation** it induces on the strands.
425: 
426: **Explicit formula on generators**:
427: 
428: $$
429: \rho(\sigma_i) = \tau_i = (i \, i+1) \in S_N
430: 
431: $$
432: 
433: the transposition swapping positions $i$ and $i+1$.
434: 
435: The **kernel** of $\rho$ is the **pure braid group** $P_N$:
436: 
437: $$
438: 1 \to P_N \to B_N \xrightarrow{\rho} S_N \to 1
439: 
440: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-186
hints.content:
444: 
445: :::{prf:proof}
446: **Well-definedness**: The assignment $\rho(\sigma_i) = (i \, i+1)$ extends to a group homomorphism because:
447: - Far commutativity: $(i \, i+1)$ and $(j \, j+1)$ commute when $|i - j| \geq 2$ ✓
448: - Braid relation: Both sides give the 3-cycle $(i \, i+1 \, i+2)$ ✓
449: 
450: **Surjectivity**: Any permutation in $S_N$ can be written as a product of adjacent transpositions, so $\rho$ is surjective.

hints.label: def-parallel-transport-braid
hints.title: Parallel Transport Along Spatial Paths
hints.content:
460: :label: def-parallel-transport-braid
461: 
462: Let $\gamma: [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ be a path in the non-singular spatial configuration space with $\gamma(0) = [x_1^0, \ldots, x_N^0]$ and $\gamma(1) = [x_1^1, \ldots, x_N^1]$.
463: 
464: The **parallel transport map** acts on the fibers of the state configuration space:
465: 
466: $$
467: \mathcal{T}_\gamma: p^{-1}([x_1^0, \ldots, x_N^0]) \to p^{-1}([x_1^1, \ldots, x_N^1])
468: 
469: $$
470: 
471: defined by:
472: 
473: $$
474: \mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S}) = \rho([\gamma]) \cdot \mathcal{S}
475: 
476: $$
477: 
478: where:
479: - $[\gamma] \in B_N(\mathcal{X})$ is the braid class represented by the spatial path $\gamma$
480: - $\rho([\gamma]) \in S_N$ is the permutation induced by the braid (via Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-braid-to-permutation`)
481: - The action $\cdot$ is the natural $S_N$-action on $\Sigma_N$
482: - $p$ is the projection from state to spatial configuration space (Definition {prf:ref}`def-state-spatial-config`)
hints.section: ## 3. The Braid Group and Gauge Connection
hints.raw_directive:
457: We now define the gauge connection rigorously as a rule for parallel transport along paths in the **spatial configuration space** $\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$.
458: 
459: :::{prf:definition} Parallel Transport Along Spatial Paths
460: :label: def-parallel-transport-braid
461: 
462: Let $\gamma: [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ be a path in the non-singular spatial configuration space with $\gamma(0) = [x_1^0, \ldots, x_N^0]$ and $\gamma(1) = [x_1^1, \ldots, x_N^1]$.
463: 
464: The **parallel transport map** acts on the fibers of the state configuration space:
465: 
466: $$
467: \mathcal{T}_\gamma: p^{-1}([x_1^0, \ldots, x_N^0]) \to p^{-1}([x_1^1, \ldots, x_N^1])
468: 
469: $$
470: 
471: defined by:
472: 
473: $$
474: \mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S}) = \rho([\gamma]) \cdot \mathcal{S}
475: 
476: $$
477: 
478: where:
479: - $[\gamma] \in B_N(\mathcal{X})$ is the braid class represented by the spatial path $\gamma$
480: - $\rho([\gamma]) \in S_N$ is the permutation induced by the braid (via Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-braid-to-permutation`)
481: - The action $\cdot$ is the natural $S_N$-action on $\Sigma_N$
482: - $p$ is the projection from state to spatial configuration space (Definition {prf:ref}`def-state-spatial-config`)

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-228
hints.title: Global vs. Local Parallel Transport
hints.content:
488: :class: note
489: 
490: The definition of parallel transport via $\mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S}) = \rho([\gamma]) \cdot \mathcal{S}$ is **global**: it depends on the entire path $\gamma$ through its homotopy class $[\gamma] \in B_N(\mathcal{X})$.
491: 
492: **Standard definition**: In differential geometry, a connection is typically defined **locally** via horizontal subspaces or a connection 1-form, specifying how to lift infinitesimal path segments.
493: 
494: **Why the global definition is valid**: Our connection is **flat** (zero curvature in the differential-geometric sense). For flat connections, parallel transport depends only on the homotopy class of the path, not its specific parametrization. This allows the equivalent and more convenient global definition via $\rho: \pi_1(\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}) = B_N(\mathcal{X}) \to S_N$.

hints.label: thm-parallel-transport-well-defined
hints.title: Well-Definedness of Parallel Transport
hints.section: ## 3. The Braid Group and Gauge Connection

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-246
hints.content:
504: 
505: :::{prf:proof}
506: **Well-definedness on fibers**: Fix spatial positions $[x_1, \ldots, x_N] \in \mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$. The fiber $p^{-1}([x_1, \ldots, x_N])$ consists of all states $(x_{\sigma(1)}, v_1, s_1, \ldots, x_{\sigma(N)}, v_N, s_N)$ for $\sigma \in S_N$.
507: 
508: If $\mathcal{S}, \mathcal{S}'$ lie in the same fiber, they differ by a permutation: $\mathcal{S}' = \sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}$ for some $\sigma \in S_N$. Then:
509: 
510: $$
511: \mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S}') = \rho([\gamma]) \cdot (\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}) = (\rho([\gamma]) \circ \sigma) \cdot \mathcal{S}
512: 
513: $$
514: 
515: Both $\mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S})$ and $\mathcal{T}_\gamma(\mathcal{S}')$ lie in the same fiber over the endpoint of $\gamma$, so the map is well-defined as a map between fibers.
516: 
517: **Flatness**: The holonomy around any closed loop $\gamma$ in $\mathcal{M}'^{\text{spatial}}_{\text{config}}$ with $\gamma(0) = \gamma(1)$ is the permutation $\rho([\gamma]) \in S_N$. Since $\rho: B_N(\mathcal{X}) \to S_N$ is a group homomorphism, holonomies compose:
518: 
519: $$
520: \text{Hol}(\gamma_1 \star \gamma_2) = \rho([\gamma_1 \star \gamma_2]) = \rho([\gamma_1]) \circ \rho([\gamma_2]) = \text{Hol}(\gamma_1) \circ \text{Hol}(\gamma_2)
521: 
522: $$

hints.title: Holonomy for Closed Loops
hints.content:
530: :label: def-holonomy-braid
531: 
532: For a closed loop $\gamma: [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}'_{\text{config}}$ with $\gamma(0) = \gamma(1) = [\mathcal{S}_0]$, the **holonomy** is the permutation:
533: 
534: $$
535: \text{Hol}(\gamma) = \rho([\gamma]) \in S_N
536: 
537: $$

hints.title: Curvature and Flatness
hints.content:
560: :label: def-curvature-braid
561: 
562: The gauge connection is **flat** on the non-singular configuration space $\mathcal{M}'_{\text{config}}$ in the sense that:
563: 
564: $$
565: \text{Hol}(\gamma \star \gamma') = \text{Hol}(\gamma) \circ \text{Hol}(\gamma')
566: 
567: $$
568: 
569: for all loops $\gamma, \gamma'$ (holonomies compose as group elements).
570: 
571: However, the connection has **non-trivial global topology**: there exist loops $\gamma$ such that:
572: 
573: $$
574: \text{Hol}(\gamma) \neq e
575: 
576: $$
